results.title: Rome and Pompeii
results.brief_description: The magnificence or Rome and Pompeii as they were about 2,000 years ago is reconstructed before your eyes. See the Colosseum, as it stood, with 50,000 Romans applauding the bloody gladiator spectacles. Walk the Roman Forum in all its splendour. See the Circus Maximus where 150,000 cheered the chariot races. Gaze at the lavish lifestyles in both Rome and Pompeii - the baths, theatres, temples, palaces and shopping markets. Watch Neros Rome ablaze and Mount Vesuvius devastation of Pompeii, recreated as it might have happened.

results.title: The Wild bunch (S)
results.creator_credit: Sam Peckinpah, Phil Feldman and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: In 1913, a gang known as “The Wild Bunch”, rode into a Texas border town disguised as U.S. soldiers. Silently they entered the railroad office and robbed it. Perched on the rooftops above was a ring of hired gunmen waiting for their prey. When the gang emerged they opened fire. An exciting, provocative and influential film that breathed new life into Westerns, it brings together an all-star cast of fine actors at the peak of their talents to play the band of magnificent losers in a dying, lawless West.

results.title: Eating Raoul
results.creator_credit: Paul Bartel, Anne Kimmel, International Classis, Quartet, Quartet Films and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Paul and Mary Bland, an endearingly middle-class couple, want to get out of their swinger-infested apartment building and open a nice little restaurant in the country. However, real estate is expensive and Paul has just lost his job. So, they take out a kinky ad and then knock off the rich swingers who answer it…Enter Raoul.

results.title: Shifting Sands: from sand to celluloid continued...
results.brief_description: This video contains six short films about the lives of Aboriginal Australians living in today’s society. “Tears”, directed by Ivan Sen, is the story of a teenage couple as they walk from their northern mission station to a bus stop and await a new life with the girl’s father, who perhaps doesn’t know they are coming and who probably doesn’t care anyway. “My colour, your kind”, directed by Danielle McLean, is the journey through and to uncertainty of an albino Aboriginal girl who escapes from a severe Catholic mission to trek barefoot in a nightie across the outback. “Passing through”, directed by Mark Olive, a young family on their way to visit relatives pass through an old gold mining town. As the woman begins to delve into memories of her childhood, the family leave to continue their journey. Has she missed the opportunity to discover the secrets of the past? “Promise”, directed by Mitch Torres, is the tale of an old woman overseeing her grand-daughter making damper when she is asked how it came to be that she was betrothed at a young age. “My bed, your bed”, directed by Erica Glynn, in an isolated desert community, the time has come for two young people promised to each other under traditional law to move in together. Things don’t run as smoothly as they might. “Grace”, directed by Wesley Enoch, Grace is a middle-aged woman, living a comfortable life but when she returns to the mission where she grew up for the funeral of her sister she is confronted by the family she never met.

results.title: Queensland's first films 1895-1910
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Almost all of Queensland’s film production for the 1890s has survived, and it offers a rare opportunity to see Australias colonial era come to life. This video contains highlights of the motion picture legacy of the of the pioneering exhibitors and filmmakers. Thoroughly researched and narrated by film historian Chris Long, this video opens a window into the colonial era and is a timely reminder of the crucial role played by factual film in the film in the first hundred years of cinema.

results.title: Border images: Albury-Wodonga 1920s-1970s
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Recapture the essence of Albury-Wodonga, the twin border cities on the Murray River. Delight in the landscapes of the past, recall the unique growth and progress of these twin cities: Hume Weir construction ; the intrigue of the Pyjama Murder mystery, travel on the Spirit of Progresses inaugural journey ; race in the 1930 Albury Gold Cup ; fly the Centenary Air Race with Bert Hinkler ; laugh with the old times of Albury-Wodonga and follow the frolicking fun of days gone by.
results.creator_credit_for_label: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia

results.title: Sons of Matthew
results.creator_credit: Charles Chauvel, Elsa Chauvel and Expeditionary Films
results.brief_description: This is the story of three generations of the O’Riordan family, battling bushfire, drought and cyclone to settle rugged frontier land. Based on the true story of the O’Reilly family, it took two years to make this film in the wild mountain terrain of southeastern Queensland. In this film Charles Chauvel realises his romantic vision of Australians as spirited rural people conquering a hostile land. Its power lies in the strong performances of the cast and in the striking landscape, which frames the human and elemental conflicts.

results.title: Heritage
results.brief_description: Heritage explores 150 years of Australian history through the nationals myths of the visionary, the pioneer and the nation-builder. Opening with an historical re-enactment, this film evolves into a fictional story of the hard-living, hard-drinking James Morrison and his wife, fiery Irish girl, Biddy OShea. Although they go their separate ways, their paths and those of their children, cross as a nations destiny unfolds. Working with a very small budget , Chauvel was still able to achieve striking set pieces, such as the opening tableau. This film won the first prize in the 1935 Commonwealth Government film competition. For a nation emerging from the Great Depression, it showed pride in the past and faith in the future

results.title: Stolen moments
results.creator_credit: Margaret Wescott, Silva Basmajian and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Narrated by Kate Nelligan, the film takes us on an odyssey across North America and Europe to capture the ‘stolen moments’ of lesbian history. Lesbian culture in pre-war Paris, Berlin and Amsterdam; the experience of women in Nazi concentration camps; and the butch/femme scene in New York in the 1950s, are just a few aspects of lesbian history and identity explored in this provocative film. Writers Joan Nestle, Leslie Feinberg and Audrey Lorde share their insights of love, life, sexual politics and feminism. The film also explores such contemporary cultural scenes as women’s motorcycle clubs, dance bars, lesbian stand-up comedy, the Michigan Women’s Music Festival and lesbian athletes and their participation at the Vancouver Gay Games. A press kit complements the video and is issued as a separate loan item.
